etymologies: late 16th century; earliest use found in Richard Harvey (d. 1630), astrologer and polemicist. From bear + herd, probably as an alteration of bearard, variant of bearward, with reanalysis of the second element as a reduced form of herd

definitions: In Britain: a person who takes care of bears, bulls, apes, or other animals, training and managing them for displays of public entertainment, such as baiting and dancing.
